awd_titl_txt: A Comprehensive Spectroscopic Study of Gravitationally Lensed Dwarf Galaxies at the Peak Epoch of Star Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will study the most distant dwarf galaxies known to astronomers.  The dwarf galaxies are located behind clusters of galaxies.  Gravitational lensing by the foreground clusters boosts the signals from the distant dwarf galaxies.  This trick lets the team observe the otherwise-invisible dwarf galaxies.  Observations from the ground and space will show how the dwarf galaxies form their stars and affect their environments.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The team will engage with underrepresented students in local high schools, notably those of the Riverside County Juvenile Halls.  The team will also develop online materials for teacher training.

The team will investigate dwarf galaxies at z ~ 1.5-3.6.  Their goals are to (1) conduct ground-based spectroscopy at optical and near-infrared wavelengths of 200 dwarf galaxies lensed by galaxy clusters; (2) combine those measurements with existing space-based measurements; and (3) examine the Lyman continuum escape fractions, the dust extinction, the gas outflows, the metallicities, and the "burstiness" of the star formation.

por.por_cntn:
We have used two instruments at the Keck Observatory to collect ultraviolet and optical (visible) spectra of faint (low mass) galaxies when the universe was only 2-3 billion years old. These galaxies were originally identified in imaging of large galaxy clusters obtained by the Hubble Space Telescope.  The gravity from these clusters acts as a lens, distorting the light and magnifying the faint galaxies behind them.  In this way, we can study galaxies that are typically too faint to observe with current telescopes. We obtained 177 spectra with the LRIS instrument, and 171 spectra with the MOSFIRE instrument.  For ~60 galaxies, we have spectra with both instruments allowing a more comprehensive study of the galaxy properties.  

The goal of these spectra is to study how quickly and efficiently these galaxies formed, their contribution to ionizing the hydrogen in the universe, and creating the heavy elements (more massive than hydrogen and helium). 

Several results have been published from these data.  First, these spectra were used in two papers to refine the models of the cluster gravitational “lenses,” to better understand the magnification of these background galaxies.  Second, these data were used in two additional papers to verify the distance to these faint galaxies to determine how numerous they were. The findings suggest a very large population of low-mass galaxies that were not seen/verified before, that contribute significantly to the star formation in the early universe.  Third, these spectra were used in two additional papers (one in preparation still) to determine the “metallicity” (how much of the heavier elements are present relative to hydrogen), and the dependence of this on the galaxies’ masses.  This is an important parameter to understand how efficiently stars form in the early universe. It appears that theses lower mass galaxies have metallicities in line with extrapolations of trends in brighter galaxies that were previously studied. Fourth, the spectra were used in another paper to determine that these faint galaxies produce ~10%-30% more ionizing photons than brighter galaxies, per unit of star formation rate, and were likley important contributors to the destruction (ionization) of most of the hydrogen in the universe 13 billion years ago.  Finally, these spectra are being used in a paper (still in preparation) to better understand the ability of the Lyman-alpha line (an extremely important line for identifying distant galaxies) to escape from galaxies. 

In addition to the science goals above, the scientists involved on this project conducted an outreach program at Butterfield Juvenile Hall in Riverside, CA, to get the youth there excited about science. We also gave presentations and classes to high school physics teachers from inland Southern California to update their understanding of physics, suggest effective demonstrations for their classes, and update them on the latest astrophysics research.
